questions.question: Which of the following factors increases the risk of femoral neck fractures?
questions.explanation: Proton pump inhibitors can increase the risk of osteoporosis-related fractures, including femoral neck fractures, by reducing calcium absorption.

questions.question: Which of the following classifications is not used for neck of femur fractures?
questions.explanation: Neer's classification is used for proximal humeral fractures. Classifications used for neck of femur fracture are: Based on the location of the fracture line, Pauwels classification, Garden classification, and Delbet classification (hip fractures in the pediatric population). Based on the location of the fracture line, it can be classified as: Sub-capital fracture at the junction of head and neck, Transcervical fracture in the neck, and Basal-cervical - fracture at the base of the neck. Pauwels classification of fracture neck of femur: Reference line, Fracture line, I stage <30° (30-50% 50°). Type I, Type II, Type III. Incomplete fracture line. Garden classification of fracture neck of femur: II Stage Complete fracture line; non-displaced, III Stage Complete fracture line; partially displaced (All three sets of trabeculae are out of alignment), IV stage Complete fracture line; completely displaced (Trabeculae between acetabulum and head are realigned). Delbet classification is used for hip fractures in children. They are grouped into four types based on their location as follows: Type I Transepiphyseal fracture, Type II - Transcervical fracture, Type III Cervicotrochanteric fracture, Type IV - Intertrochanteric fracture.

questions.question: The X-ray of a patient with femoral neck fracture showed that all 3 sets of trabeculae were out of alignment. Which Garden's stage of fracture shows this finding?
questions.explanation: In Garden's stage III fracture of the neck of femur, all the 3 sets of trabeculae are out of alignment. Garden classification of fracture of the neck of femur is based on the degree of displacement. Stage I: incomplete fracture line and femoral head is in slight valgus. Stage II: complete fracture line and non-displaced. Stage III: complete fracture line and partially displaced. Stage IV: complete fracture line and completely displaced. Garden classification of fracture of the neck of femur: I stage - Incomplete fracture line. II Stage - Complete fracture line; non-displaced. III stage - Complete fracture line; partially displaced (All three sets of trabeculae are out of alignment). IV stage - Complete fracture line; completely displaced (Trabeculae between acetabulum and head are realigned).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding Pauwel's classification of neck of femur fractures?

options.A: Pauwel's angle is inversely proportional to stability
options.B: Type 2 fracture makes an angle of 50 degrees
options.C: Plane of reference is the horizontal plane
options.D: Pauwel's angle is formed by fracture line with the inter-trochanteric line

questions.explanation: The plane of reference in Pauwel's classification is the horizontal plane. This classification is based on Pauwel's angle, i.e., the angle made by the fracture line in reference to the horizontal plane. Pauwel's classification of fracture neck of femur: Reference line - Fracture line <30° - 30-50% - 50° - Type I - Type II - Type III. When the Pauwel's angle is small, compressive forces act at the fracture ends and hence the fracture is stable. As Pauwel's angle increases, the fracture line becomes more vertical and the shearing forces act on the fractured ends. Hence, at higher angles, the fracture becomes unstable.

questions.question: An elderly patient slipped in the bathroom and sustained an injury over the left hip. The radiograph is shown below. His attitude of the leg will be:
questions.explanation: The history of a fall and hip injury in an elderly patient, along with the radiological findings of a broken Shenton's line, is suggestive of a neck of femur fracture. In this condition, the attitude of the leg will be shortened and externally rotated, and movements of the hip joint will be painful. A plain radiograph may show the following features: • Fracture line in the neck of femur • External rotation of the femur with the lesser trochanter appearing more prominent • Displacement of the greater trochanter • Break in the trabecular stream • Break in Shenton's line. Shenton's line in fracture of neck of femur: Fracture neck of femur, Shenton's line

questions.question: A 70-year-old lady, a known case of chronic osteoarthritis of the hip, has a trivial fall while climbing the stairs. Her right lower limb is in slight external rotation. An X-ray of the pelvis is shown below. What is the next step of management?
questions.explanation: The given scenario and X-ray are suggestive of a right-sided fracture of the neck of the femur, Garden stage IV. Since the patient is over 65 years old with existing arthritis, the best choice of treatment is total hip arthroplasty. In the absence of arthritis, a fracture of the neck of the femur in patients over 65 years is treated by hemiarthroplasty.

questions.question: Which of the following is most commonly used for internal fixation of a fracture of the femoral neck in young adults?
questions.explanation: The most commonly used equipment for internal fixation of a fracture of the neck of the femur in young adults is multiple cannulated cancellous screws. The radiograph given below shows internal fixation of the neck of the femur fracture with cannulated cancellous screws. Option B: Dynamic hip screw is used in some cases of fracture of the neck of the femur and for the internal fixation of the intertrochanteric fractures. The image below shows a dynamic hip screw. Option C: Austin Moore's implant is an older implant used in unipolar hemiarthroplasty. Option D: Herbert screw is used in bridging a scaphoid fracture.

questions.question: A 55-year-old woman presents with complaints of right-sided hip pain and restriction of movements of the right lower limb for 3 weeks. She had a history of trivial trauma 3 weeks ago. X-ray reveals an impacted fracture of the neck of the right femur. What is the next step of management?
questions.explanation: In the given clinical scenario with a 3-week-old femoral head fracture, the next step will be to do an MRI hip. This is to evaluate the femoral head for compromise in the blood supply. Treatment of the femoral head fracture depends on the findings seen on an MRI: Femoral head shows compromised blood supply - reduction with fibular bone graft or muscle pedicle graft. Femoral head shows signs of osteonecrosis and acetabulum is normal - hemiarthroplasty. Femoral head is normal but the fracture is nearly vertical (can develop to non-union) - osteotomy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false regarding McMurray's osteotomy?

options.A: It is an oblique osteotomy in the inter-trochanteric region
options.B: It involves lateral displacement and adduction of the distal fragment
options.C: The line of weight bearing after the osteotomy passes from the head to the distal fragment
options.D: It converts shearing stress to compressive forces

questions.explanation: In McMurray's osteotomy, the distal fragment is displaced medially and is abducted. This converts shearing stresses at the fracture site to compressive forces, promoting faster healing. McMurray's osteotomy is an oblique osteotomy directed medially upwards at the inter-trochanteric region. It is based on the biomechanical principle. After the medial displacement of the femur, the weight-bearing line passes from the head to the distal fragment. It, therefore, bypasses the fracture site.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman with a history of ORIF for femoral neck fracture came for post-operative follow-up after 7 months. She is unable to bear weight on the operated side. Her X-ray showed no evidence of healing. Which of the following is not a probable cause for this condition?

options.D: Hypertrophy of cambium layer of periosteum

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of non-union of femoral neck fracture after ORIF, as there is no evidence of healing 6-12 months post-operatively. Lack of cambium layer in the periosteum of the neck of femur is one of the causes of non-union. Causes for non-union in the neck of femur fracture are as follows: Inadequate blood supply of the femoral head. Since the fracture is intra-articular, the synovial fluid interferes with fracture healing. Lack of the cambium layer of periosteum, which produces the callus. Inadequate reduction and poor internal fixation. Improper immobilization.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about the condition shown in the image below?

options.A: Malunion can happen if this condition is not treated
options.B: The patient may be able to walk
options.C: Avascular necrosis is the most common complication
options.D: Shortening of limb is less than 1 inch

questions.explanation: The radiograph shows a fracture of the neck of the femur. Non-union is a complication of this fracture, not malunion. Malunion is a complication of intertrochanteric fractures. Complications of fracture of the neck of the femur are: avascular necrosis (most common), non-union, and osteonecrosis of the femoral head may lead to secondary osteoarthritis after many years. Option B: In an impacted fracture of the neck of the femur, the patient may be able to walk. Option D: Shortening of the limb is less than 1 inch in a fracture of the neck of the femur.

questions.question: Which of the following is false about avascular necrosis?

options.A: It can be diagnosed on X-ray only after 4 years
options.B: It can also occur in united fracture neck of femur
options.D: Patients with sickle cell disease are at an increased risk

questions.explanation: Avascular necrosis is a late complication of fracture neck of the femur, which can be diagnosed on X-ray only after a few months to 2 years after the injury. Hence, MRI is the best investigation for diagnosis. The amount of vascular damage produced at the time of fracture determines the probability of the development of osteonecrosis. In addition to this, the blood supply to the femoral head may also be disrupted during internal fixation. Hence, avascular necrosis can also occur in united femur fractures. More proximally the fracture is located, worse is the prognosis. Hence, sub-capital fractures have the worst prognosis. Patients with sickle cell disease are at an increased risk for developing avascular necrosis of the femoral head.

questions.question: A 35-year-old man is brought to the casualty with a history of RTA. His left lower limb is shortened by 2 inches. The attitude of the leg is extension and externally rotated, with the lateral border of the foot touching the bed. What is the most probable diagnosis?

options.B: Fracture of the neck of the femur

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with the limb shortening >1 inch and pronounced external rotation is suggestive of an intertrochanteric fracture of the femur. Differences between fracture of the neck of the femur and intertrochanteric fractures: Option B: In a fracture of the neck of the femur, the limb is in slight external rotation and shortening is <1 inch. Option C: In femoral shaft fractures, the limb is shortened with displaced proximal and distal fragments. Option D: In an anterior dislocation of the hip, the limb is externally rotated. There may be a true lengthening of the limb with the femoral head palpable in the groin. Features: Age - More than 50 years for fracture of the neck of the femur, More than 60 years for intertrochanteric fracture; Sex - Common in females for fracture of the neck of the femur, Common in males for intertrochanteric fracture; Injury - Trivial for fracture of the neck of the femur, Significant for intertrochanteric fracture; Ability to walk - May walk for fracture of the neck of the femur, Unable to walk for intertrochanteric fracture; Pain - Mild for fracture of the neck of the femur; Swelling - Nil for fracture of the neck of the femur; Ecchymosis and tenderness - In Scarpa's triangle for fracture of the neck of the femur, On the greater trochanter for intertrochanteric fracture; External rotation deformity - Less than 45 degrees for fracture of the neck of the femur, More than 45 degrees for intertrochanteric fracture; Shortening - Less than 1 inch for fracture of the neck of the femur, More than 1 inch for intertrochanteric fracture; Treatment - Internal fixation always for fracture of the neck of the femur, Can be managed in traction for intertrochanteric fracture; Complications - Avascular necrosis and non-union for fracture of the neck of the femur, Malunion for intertrochanteric fracture.

questions.question: A 69-year-old woman sustains an injury to the left hip after falling sideways on the floor. She is unable to move the left leg. X-ray is given below. What is the best treatment for this condition?

options.D: Plaster in abduction and internal rotation

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario and the X-ray is suggestive of an intertrochanteric fracture of the left femur, which is best treated by closed reduction and internal fixation with a proximal femoral nail. The image given below shows an intertrochanteric fracture corrected with a proximal femoral nail. The intertrochanteric fractures of the femur can be treated by: Internal fixation with: Intramedullary implants - proximal femoral nail and gamma nail; Extramedullary implants - dynamic hip screw; Traction: Russell's traction, Thomas splint. Compared to the dynamic hip screw, the intramedullary fixation with proximal femoral nails has smaller incisions, decreased blood loss, decreased femoral neck shortening, and decreased risk of infection.

questions.question: A 68-year-old lady comes with a history of a fall and right-sided hip pain for 1 week. On examination, her right limb is shortened and externally rotated. Her X-ray shows no significant findings. What is your next step?

options.A: Send the patient home with analgesics for pain
options.B: Technetium bone scan within the next 24 hours
options.C: Order an MRI of the hip joint

questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of an occult neck of femur fracture, as the X-ray is normal but the attitude of the leg is abnormal. In such cases, MRI is the imaging study of choice. Both CT and MRI can detect the presence of a fracture of the neck of the femur. However, MRI can demonstrate the presence of soft tissue problems that can cause hip pain. It also does not expose the patient to radiation. Hence, MRI is preferred over CT in the diagnosis of occult femoral neck fractures. Technetium bone scan is an older method to detect occult fractures. They are less specific and may not show the presence of a fracture if performed within 48-72 hours and in osteopenic bones.

questions.question: A young patient was brought to the casualty following a road traffic accident. The radiograph of the limb showed a fracture in the mid-shaft of the femur. What will be the direction of displacement of the distal fragment?
questions.explanation: In the fracture of the midshaft of the femur, the distal fragment is adducted as the adductors and the gastrocnemius are attached to the lower part of the femur. The proximal fragment is flexed and externally rotated as the gluteus medius and iliopsoas muscles are attached to the upper part of the femur. Displacement of the fractured ends in the femoral shaft fracture: Proximal fragment - Abduction and external rotation. Displacement of fracture fragments in the fracture shaft of the femur: Site of fracture - Proximal femoral shaft fractures, Mid-shaft femoral fractures, Distal femoral shaft fractures. Displacement of the proximal segment - Flexed, abducted, and externally rotated. Displacement of the distal fragment - Adducted. Flexed and externally rotated with minimal abduction - Adducted. Adducted - Tilted by gastrocnemius pull

questions.question: In which of the following conditions is maximum shortening of the lower limb seen?

options.B: Fracture of the neck of the femur
options.C: Fracture of the shaft of the femur

questions.explanation: From the given options, maximum shortening of the lower limb is seen in the intertrochanteric fracture of the femur. Overall, the maximum shortening of lower limbs is seen in posterior dislocation of the hip, followed by an intertrochanteric fracture of the femur.

questions.question: A 24-year-old patient was brought to the emergency department after he lost control of his bike and hit a car while texting and driving. On examination, the patient had right thigh tenderness and deformity. The radiograph showed the following findings. What is the preferred method of treatment in the following scenario?
questions.explanation: The above radiograph shows a fracture in the shaft of the femur with the displacement of fractured ends. The preferred method of treatment in this condition is an intramedullary nail with locking screws. Option A: Plating can be done in cases of comminuted fractures. Option C: External fixation is preferred in the treatment of severe open injuries, or when there is severe bone loss that may require a bone graft. Option D: Thomas splint is used in the emergency treatment of shaft of femur fracture and some supracondylar fractures. The main indications for traction are: (1) fractures in children, (2) contraindications to anesthesia or surgery, (3) lack of suitable skill or facilities for internal fixation.

questions.question: A 9-year-old girl was run over by a car and was admitted to the hospital with obvious swelling and deformity of the left thigh. Her X-ray showed the following findings. What will be the preferred treatment in the given condition?
questions.explanation: The preferred treatment in children of ages 5-10 years with fracture shaft of the femur is elastic intramedullary nailing. The image given below shows fracture shaft of femur treated with elastic intramedullary nailing.

questions.question: A patient was admitted to ICU 48 hours after the fracture of the femur. The saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his SpO2 remained 60%. The patient was in a state of confusion. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation: In this clinical scenario, the presence of reduced SpO2 and altered mental status in a patient presenting within 72 hours following a long bone fracture suggests the diagnosis of a fat embolism. Fat embolism is caused by the fat globules originating from the bone marrow following the fracture of long bones. Clinical features of fat embolism are usually seen within 72 hours. They include tachycardia, fever, breathlessness, petechiae, confusion, and restlessness. Gurd's criteria are used for the diagnosis of fat embolism syndrome. There is no specific diagnostic test for fat embolism. However, urine analysis to detect fat globules and monitoring of blood pO2 levels are conducted. The management of fat embolism primarily involves supportive care, including oxygen therapy and prompt stabilization of long-bone fractures. Option A: Pulmonary embolism most commonly occurs as a result of thrombi from deep vein thrombosis of the leg. Option C: Acute respiratory distress syndrome is diagnosed using the Berlin's criteria. All four of the following conditions must be met: it develops within 1 week of clinical insult or worsening respiratory symptoms. Chest radiograph shows bilateral opacities consistent with pulmonary edema. These opacities are not fully explained by effusions, lobar or lung collapse, or nodules. The edema is not due to cardiac failure, or fluid overload. There is impaired oxygenation. The ratio of arterial oxygen partial pressure to the fraction of inspired oxygen (PaO2/FiO2) is ≤ 300 mmHg as assessed on 5 cm H2O of positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP). Option D: Occult pneumothorax is a condition that is not suspected on the basis of the symptoms or plain radiography, but is detected with CT imaging. It usually follows a thoracic injury.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a minor criterion for diagnosing fat embolism?
questions.explanation: Fat globules in sputum is a minor criterion for diagnosing fat embolism.
